bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, December 9, 1944

div1.p: Kean relates a humorous anecdote about Wood. Kean goes on to discuss the problems of finding the exact moment when Guiteras was converted to the mosquito theory. He also discusses Pinto's role in the Yellow Fever Commission.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, December 9, 1944
div1.opener:
P. S. To' letter of Dec. 6.
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7. D. C.
Dec. 9th/44
My dear Col. Hench
div1.p:
This is the rather delayed P.S. to
my letter of the 6th I was glad to get
the pictures of Señora Raquel Romero
She had Mrs on her visiting card
when she was here. It is fine that
you will be able to get home for
Christmas. As regards my fatherly
advice to you I did not intend it to
be in that way at all, but I felt that
you were not very clear in your mind
as to the legal limitations to the author-
ity of a commanding officer. This is quite
natural as many commanding officers
do not themselves appreciate them.
There is no military authority which
2
can compel you to change a diagnosis
and if a C.O. wants it or wants the
line of duty changed from yes to no or
vice versa, he cannot do it over your
signature, but would have to initial the
change himself, or have a reexamination
by another officer. Gen. Leonard Wood,
who was a great man and would have been
President instead of the inept Harding,* was
a Major. Gen training a division in the
west for the World War, and told this
story: He was driving along a country
road when he saw one of his men, a
private walking along the road with his
girl. When they saw the General's Car
with the two stars on the wind-shield
they turned off the road, as the recruit
did not want his girl see him have to
*if he had been willing to let the elder statesmen of the
Republican Party dictate who should be in his cabinet.
3
make a salute. So the General stopped
his car and called the soldier to him
and said to him in a low tone. You
must not feel ashamed to salute an
officer. It is not the man that you salute
but the uniform and authority of the U.S.
and the officer is as much obliged to
return the salute as you are to make it.
So the next time you see an officer coming
when you are with your best girl, just
say to her “Now watch me make that old
Duffer salute me”_ then you stand up
and salute me, and I will certainly
return it, and your girl will see what a
fine thing it is to wear a uniform“-

As regards the Y F papers I will
get a box and when I clean up my
old files I will put into it everything
relating to the Episode and will send it
AC
K
4
to your home office. But this will
be a matter of times and occasions
and will not be there for you to
go over at Christmas. You can use
your ten days to better purpose than
that. I have a fine letter from
Gen Truby this morning. He tells
me that he has sent you a copy of
the letter I wrote to Dr. Ramos.
That which I wrote you is a better
presentation however as I had looked
up & quoted in my letter to you what
Dr. Carlos E. Finlay said in his book
I made that letter all on that subject
so if you chose to send a copy of it
to Dr. Albertini you could do so.
Truly expressed himself as much pleas-
ed with the letter to Dr Ramos and
has sent you a copy of it. He thinks
that it will be fine if you will han-
dle this matter. I think Dr. A's proposition
is absurd and when the proposition is put
up to them to prove the exact moment when Guiteras was
converted 44 years ago they will drop the matter I hope so

closer.seg:
I inclose the notice of Dr Pintos death.
I think that none of the first group
who were bitten at the hospital at
Columbia Bks took the matter seriously
or believed in the mosquito theory.
You will remember that none of them
volunteered for the Camp Lazear exper-
iments - tho. I think that Pinto had
left Cuba by that time and had gone
to the Philippines.
